Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Common Problem Pedagogy Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The economic prosperity of the United States relies on progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. This prosperity relies on a talented workforce with the ability to nimbly address new challenges and develop innovative technologies. The Common Problem Pedagogy project seeks to improve STEM teaching and learning through the integration of cross-disciplinary experiences and applied learning opportunities in ways that will strengthen STEM workforce preparation and produce a more STEM-literate public. STEM faculty will partner with one or more colleagues from the arts and humanities to identify a community partner with a significant problem or issue relevant to their disciplines. Each faculty member will incorporate problem-based learning activities in their courses to address the problem. Interdisciplinary teams of students from their classes will work together, applying the perspectives and tools of inquiry from their respective disciplines, to develop potential solutions that will be presented to the community partner at the end of the semester.

This project will be implemented on four SUNY Campuses: Cortland, Oneonta, Oswego, and Plattsburgh. The goals of the project are to demonstrate the effectiveness of Common Problem Pedagogy on student learning within STEM disciplines, to increase the number of STEM instructors proficient in this pedagogy, and to identify strategies for scaling up this methodology for large-scale adoption across the SUNY system and beyond. Thirty-two faculty members from the four campuses will participate in professional development opportunities to learn about the new pedagogy, implement it in their classes, and then evaluate the impact of this approach on the achievement of student learning outcomes related to problem-solving using interdisciplinary approaches. A train-the-trainer model will be adopted, whereby participating faculty members recruit additional faculty members to participate in future semesters. The principal investigators will gather data from participating faculty and community partners to identify challenges associated with implementing this method, and to evaluate students' success in working with community partners in cross-disciplinary teams to address meaningful, real-world problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We implemented and assessed a novel teaching method, the Common Problem Pedagogy, that integrates problem-solving, interdisciplinary teamwork, and service learning to improve STEM education, increase student retention, and promote community engagement. As a collaboration across five SUNY campuses, this project has strengthened our shared commitment to undertake new methods to best educate our students. We trained 32 faculty members from STEM and humanities/arts disciplines to strengthen their teaching by coupling their courses to address a common problem of interest to students and the community. Students learned that disciplinary silos hinder problem-solving and worked across disciplines to apply their specialized knowledge to address a shared problem. The problem commonly included interactions with local stakeholders.

 

More than 700 students participated in real-world applied learning experiences that put their education into practice and studied issues that included the stigma of opioid addiction, climate change denial, antibiotic use in farm animals, equitable solutions to mitigate climate change, land use in the Adirondack Park, nutrition in K-12 schools, the improvement of athletic performance, the application of GIS to map patterns in crime, the history of  environmental impacts from political policies on local communities, among others.

 

As a group, we have been able to construct and analyze assessment of student learning that has demonstrated the efficacy of our pedagogy. In particular, we have been able to show that  students ability to problem solve improves, their collaborative skills are enhanced, and that they benefit from the cross-disciplinary teamwork. In the teams, students serve as content experts to other students outside of their discipline, and learn the vocabulary and concepts of other disciplines as they solve problems together.

 

Beyond our State University of New York partners cohort, we have shared our project  with an estimated 300 colleagues at other institutions through national and regional conferences, workshops and activities. Participating  faculty have also published on the project. We produced a video for the NSF “STEM for All” event that was quite popular and received a number of comments and queries. We are now collaborating with colleges from other states to conduct a virtual workshop on problem-based learning and collaborative work.  Our work continues as we complete a manuscript documenting our course content and pedagogy, which will further disseminate the results of our NSF-funded work to the greater community.
